direct_enhancements.reason: Both methods search for elements based on specific criteria (ID vs. tag name) but share similar traversal and matching logic.
Both methods search for elements based on specific attributes (ID vs. class name) and share similar traversal and matching logic.
Both methods can be used to find elements, but `select` uses CSS selectors which are more flexible and can replace `getElementById` in many scenarios.
Similar to `getElementById`, `selectFirst` finds the first matching element using a CSS selector, which can be more flexible.
Both methods involve finding elements based on a query, but `closest` searches up the tree while `getElementById` searches down.
Similar to `getElementById`, `expectFirst` finds the first matching element using a CSS selector and throws an exception if not found.
Both methods can be used to find elements, but `selectXpath` uses XPath expressions which are more flexible and can replace `getElementById` in many scenarios.
Similar to `selectXpath(String)`, but allows specifying the node type, making it more flexible for finding specific types of elements.
